div.l: Though that he holy chirche shulde deuoure
¶ Grete soken hath this meller out of doute
With whete and malt / of al the londe aboute
And namely / ther was a grete college
Men clepen the Soler halle of Caumbrigge
There was her whete / and hir malt ygrounde
And on a day / it happed in a stounde
Syk lay the manciple / on a maladye
Men wende wisly / that he shulde dye
For whiche the Miller / stale bothe mele and corn̄
An hundred tyme more / than biforn̄
For ther biforn̄ he stale but curteisly
But now he was a theef outrageously
For whiche the wardeyn̄ chidde and made fare
But thereof sette the Miller nouȝt a tare
He craked bost / and it was nouȝt so
Than were there yonge scolers two
That dwelte in the halle / of whiche I seye
Testif they were / and lusty forto pleye
And only for her merthe / and her reuerie
Vpon̄ the wardeyn̄ / besily they crie
To yeve hem leve but a lytel stounde
To goon to mylle / and seen her corn ygrounde
And hardely they durste leie her nekke
The meller sholde not stele hem half a pekke
Of corn / ne by sligthe / ne by force hem reve
And at the laste / the wardeyn̄ yaf hem leve
Iohn highte that oon / and Aleyn highte the other
Of oo toun were they born̄ / that highte Strother
Fer in the north / I can not tellen where
This Aleyn̄ maketh redy / al his gere
And on an hors / the sak he caste anoon
Forth goth Aleyn̄ / the clerk and also Iohn
With goode swerde / and bokeler by his syde
Iohn knewe the weye / hym nedeth no gyde
And atte melle / the sak adoıı̄un he layeth
Aleyn̄ spak first al helye Symond in fayeth
How fares thy fayre doughter and thy wyf
